title: Chase released lien / Debt still owed
question: I have a first & second mortgage & the house is underwater. Its almost back up to the amount of the first mortgage. Almost.. It was bought in 2005. Due to financial circumstances I & my co-borrower have not paid on the second in approx. 5-6 years. The first is current but only paying the interest as in the terms of the loan till 2016. The loans have been passed around from lender to lender. My 2nd ended up in the hands of Chase. They have just released my lien & has been recorded, which should be good news. However that did not relieve my obligation to pay the note. I had to file for Chapter 7 in 2012 & my co - borrower 7 yrs ago. However that still does not wipe out my debt as at that time it was a secured loan. The note is for 125,000.00. My worry is that now its an unsecured loan, Chase can sue for a judgment for payment. And if we can't make the payment and Chase is awarded the judgment wages will be garnished.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Mortgage lien,Lien,Secured debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Home mortgage,Real estate,Mortgage debt
answers: A Chapter 7 bankruptcy discharge will apply to all debt you owe as of the date of the filing of the bankruptcy. The discharge will apply to your personal liability on a secured debt. The security interest will ride through the Chapter 7 bankruptcy, however if the lender voluntarily releases the lien post-discharge then you now have discharged your personal liability through the Chapter 7 and the lien has been released by the creditor. Congratulations you have the best of both worlds, now you need to do a loan modification on the first mortgage to make it affordable or refinance if there is value in the property. Chase cannot sue you on a discharged obligation the only rights they had were to foreclose on the security interest, which they voluntarily released. Stop worrying. Chase released the lien because they made more money off the government guarantee or wrote you off on one of several settlements they are now involved in due to the bad practices pre bailout.

Your C 7 Bk relieved you of personal liability on the second mortgage. The lien survived thew BK. If Chase has released the lien, they no longer have a security interest in the real property. Unless you reaffirmed the loan in the C7 BK, you have no personal liability.
If lien not released, consider filing C13 to strip the lien.
I have filed follow up C13 in several cases to strip an underwater junior lien following completion of a C7 BK. Consult BK counsel to review options.

Im confused here. You wrote: "However that did not relieve my obligation to pay the note. I had to file for Chapter 7 in 2012 & my co - borrower 7 yrs ago. However that still does not wipe out my debt as at that time it was a secured loan. The note is for 125,000.00. My worry is that now its an unsecured loan, Chase can sue for a judgment for payment."

Unless either or both of you reaffirmed the debt, the debt was discharged in your respective Ch. 7 cases. Therefore, I do not see how this is an issue. The 2nd has been discharged and the lien has been released. That leaves your first mortgage.

Click on "Find a Lawyer" and speak to a debt collection defense attorney with familiarity with the 2nd lien law in CA. Generally the 2nd mortgage note can be sued on, unless it was discharged in bankruptcy with the exception of there being a reaffirmation agreement.

Seems to me the 2nd could've been stripped off the property way back when. Twice.

In my opinion, the combination of your 2012 BK in which you listed your 2nd mortgage debt together with the release of the mortgage itself is proof there is no legal basis Chase will pursue collection of the debt. It doesn't make any difference who wound up holding the 2nd TD among the several that you said "passed around the debt"

First of all, CHILL! If Chase released the lien, odds are they are not going to come after you. Take a wait and see attitude. Time is on your side. If they do come after you, sit down with an attorney to review your options then. But my suspicion is that Chase wrote off the debt when you filed your chapter 7, and they aren't coming after you.
